VLIB Function Reference

FAST

Introduction and Use Cases

FAST, like Harris Corner Score, is a feature detector algorithm. FAST stands for "Features from Accelerated Segment Test". It tends to find corner-like image textures, which are relatively easy to match between different views or to track in a video sequence. The FAST algorithm is the corner detector algorithm used by ORB.

Specification

Variants

This functionality is available in two variants: FAST9 & FAST12

Method

For each pixel, the sixteen neighborhood pixels forming a circle of radius = 3 are evaluated to determine if the center pixel qualifies as a corner. If 'N' contiguous pixels on this circle are all greater than the center pixel plus the threshold, or all less than the center pixel minus the threshold, then the center pixel is a corner. The 2 variants supported in VLIB are N=9 (FAST9), and N=12 (FAST12).

Additionally, VLIB provides two versions of each variant of the FAST detector: original, and accelerated. Although both are compiled on the DSP, the accelerated versions (afast...) are written in a more DSP optimized way with a small tradeoff of quality. So, depending on the application, both versions should be tried to see if the quality reduction in the accelerated version is tolerable given the performance boost.

Both variants of the detector also provide an API to report the FAST score for a list of corners.

Additionally, the nonmaxSuppression function removes corners from the feature list which have an adjacent corner that has a higher score.

APIS

FAST9 Variant
  • VLIB_afast9_detectCorners
  • VLIB_originalfast9_detectCorners
  • VLIB_originalfast9_score

FAST12 Variant

  • VLIB_afast12_detectCorners
  • VLIB_originalfast12_detectCorners
  • VLIB_originalfast12_score

FAST Nonmax Suppression

  • VLIB_aFast_nonmaxSuppression

References

  1. E. Rosten and T. Drummond. Fusing Points and Lines for High Performance Tracking. In IEEE International Conference on Computer Vision , 2005.
  2. E. Rosten and T. Drummond. Machine learning for high-speed corner detection. In European Conference on Computer Vision, volume 1, 2006.
